Statement.paragraph: Mr. Nicol, in your testimony, you mention that the waiver to build roads and public lands is not only environmentally destructive, but can be counterproductive to border security efforts. We have heard a lot about the east-west walls needed just on the side. Can you give an example how the public roads could be counterproductive?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Nicol

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Nicol

Statement.paragraph: Probably the best documented example is in the San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge. They are in an area that is very fissured and eroded and has deep crevices that someone cannot drive through. A patrol road was built along the southern edge of the refuge. That patrol road involved filling in lakes that are used by endangered fish. It didn't work very well because they got their bulldozers stuck when they tried to just dump dirt into it. But once the road was built, the refuge reported, in 2008, that that road was being used by smugglers, and that areas that previously had not seen any cross-border vehicle activity because one could not drive a vehicle through, were now being used by smugglers.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Nicol

Statement.paragraph: There may well be other examples that have not been as well documented. That one, because you have land banners on the ground observing it, has been.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Beyer

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Beyer

Statement.paragraph: One more question. In Mr. Judd's written testimony, he described the need for some Border Patrol agents to use horses to patrol public lands as ``absurd.'' As someone who lives on the border, do you think it is absurd that the Border Patrol may need to use horses as transports in some cases?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Nicol

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Nicol

Statement.paragraph: For me?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Beyer

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Beyer

Statement.paragraph: Yes, Mr. Nicol.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Nicol

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Nicol

Statement.paragraph: Sure. I think that it makes a lot of sense in certain areas. It doesn't make sense to create a road when a horse is a more effective way to get across that terrain. There are some very rugged parts of the border where a horse is just the most appropriate and most effective way to get from point A to point B.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Beyer

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Beyer

Statement.paragraph: Mr. Chairman, I yield back.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Westerman

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: The gentleman yields back.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: The Chair now recognizes the gentleman from Arizona, Mr. Gosar, for 5 minutes.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Gosar

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: Mr. Judd, Mr. Nicol made a comment about it is easier to pick up trash than building a wall. You are familiar with lower Santa Cruz, right?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Nicol

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Nicol

Statement.paragraph: I am, yes.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Gosar

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: What happens in the lower Santa Cruz? Mexico is high ground. We are low ground in Arizona. So, what ends up happening, we get this episodic flooding, right?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Judd

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Judd

Statement.paragraph: And we get a lot of trash washed into our areas.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Gosar

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: Not just trash, but sewage, right?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Judd

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Judd

Statement.paragraph: Yes, correct.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Gosar

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: OK. Mr. Arthur, when we start looking at disease, I would talk about trash with disease, is the antibiotic-resistant tuberculosis advancing in the United States or receding?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Arthur

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Arthur

Statement.paragraph: I know that we have seen incidents of antibiotic tuberculosis in the United States. The source of it, I cannot actually identify, but I believe it is increasing.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Gosar

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: Well, epidemiology-wise, in Arizona, it is moving farther north. OK? We have tons of illegals that come in, because we are one of the ones that actually have the treatments for that.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: So, where I am going with this is, the lower Santa Cruz, we made a comment about a wall. So, Mr. Judd, if we were to build a management of water with Mexico, would that actually be as good as a wall?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Judd

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Judd

Statement.paragraph: I am sorry?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Gosar

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: Like an infrastructure project where we actually mitigate the process and direct water along the mitigation, along the lower Santa Cruz.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Judd

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Judd

Statement.paragraph: Absolutely. What we need to do is we need to be able to keep anything that is flowing from Mexico into the United States that could be bringing trash, sewage, or anything like that. And whether that is a wall, whether that is building an infrastructure with Mexico, we just need to be able to keep that out from the United States.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Gosar

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: Let me ask you another question. Maybe you can't answer, but I have the answer. When you do something along the international border between Mexico, the United States, and Arizona, who helps pay for it?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Judd

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Judd

Statement.paragraph: The United States does, as far as I know.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Gosar

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: Can you say it? What is the other country south of us?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Judd

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Judd

Statement.paragraph: I don't know very much that Mexico pays for anything.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Gosar

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: No, but Mexico would pay for that on an infrastructure----
Statement.speaker: Mr. Judd

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Judd

Statement.paragraph: Oh, yes. In that case, yes.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Gosar

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: Absolutely, so once again, President Trump said, ``no, Mexico would pay for it,'' well, this is a creative way of looking at something that actually mitigates trauma to our infrastructure aspects that both sides take care of. And it is even better than a wall.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Judd

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Judd

Statement.paragraph: Yes.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Gosar

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: We can actually extrapolate that to Nogales because of the wastewater problem. Once again, we have rampant sewage coming into the United States from Mexico. When we do the wastewater aspect, we are the low ground, they are high ground. So, we can actually mitigate this and it makes it something that both countries mitigate.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: Oh, by the way, let me ask you the question. There is also another tribe down there, right, the Tohono O'odham that are along that border as well?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Judd

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Judd

Statement.paragraph: That is correct, yes.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Gosar

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: So, this might be an interesting facade in regards to a mitigation on how we look at border security with an infrastructure project, would it not?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Judd

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Judd

Statement.paragraph: It would, yes.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Gosar

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: Wow. Interesting. But I guess I am the racist, because that is what was said here. It is disingenuous for my colleagues on the other side to say that. Over and over again, that is all I hear.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: You know what, there is an old analogy: ``Look in the mirror. The enemy is me.''

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Gosar

Statement.paragraph: I yield back.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Westerman

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: The gentleman yields back.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: We will do one more round of questioning.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: Mr. Arthur, you stated that you observed environmental concerns in your recent visit to the Rio Grande Valley Sector that hinders border security. Can you please explain the problems that agents face there? We have been talking about the Tucson Sector in Arizona, but let's look at some other areas along the border.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Arthur

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Arthur

Statement.paragraph: The main issue that I saw when I was down there was carrizo cane. Carrizo cane is an invasive species that grows along the banks of the Rio Grande River. And to quote The New Yorker, ``it forms a grassy forest along the border within which visibility is roughly 12 to 24 inches and makes an excellent hiding space.'' It is also a woody substance. It is very difficult to get through. Once smugglers, once any sort of cross-border traffic, enter that cane, it is next to impossible to find it. There are cane eradication projects, but the cane remains. And for some reason, nothing has been done. The curious thing is that when I stood on the bluffs of Roma, Texas, and I stared across the river at Ciudad Miguel Aleman, I believe it is, I actually saw Mexican workers cutting the cane on the other side of the border, when I looked down and I saw the cane growing along our own border. I don't know why we still have it.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Westerman

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: Mr. Nicol, in your opening statement, you mentioned the San Bernardino National Wildlife Refuge as an example where border security infrastructure has failed. But you failed to note that Border Patrol's access to the refuge must be negotiated at the supervisor's level on a case-by-case basis.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: Do you think that if Border Patrol had more immediate access to the refuge's roads, it would deter illegal immigration and drug smugglers from using those roads?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Nicol

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Nicol

Statement.paragraph: I think that the interaction between the land management agencies and Border Patrol for any kind of interdiction efforts where they are both having jurisdiction is critical.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Westerman

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: I want to change the format here just a little bit. We asked a lot of questions, but there may be something on your mind that you think the Committee needs to hear that we haven't asked.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: Mr. Bell, I want to start with you. Are there any other issues regarding border security, environmental laws, regulations and access that you think we need to hear?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Bell

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Bell

Statement.paragraph: Well, it just doesn't stop with getting access to the border and waiving rules. We still need other things. We have to make sure there are boots on the ground. We have to make sure that we have aerial assets. We have to make sure they have the technology. All those things coupled together. But it doesn't stop there either.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Bell

Statement.paragraph: We need to make sure there is the infrastructure in place in the courts that allow for timely prosecutions and a judicial system that is willing to put out consequences. Only then can we really see a change if we impose consequences on folks.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Westerman

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: Being from Arkansas and making a trip down to the border like I did recently, it was really eye-opening to me the vastness of the land there, the issues that the agents face, the obstacles that are in their way.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: Mr. Judd, I want to ask you, is there something else you think the Committee should know that would enhance the Border Patrol's ability to do their job in regards to rules and regulations and environmental policy that currently is on the books?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Judd

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Judd

Statement.paragraph: Absolutely. I think that the main issue that we currently face is the access that we have to these public lands. Horse patrol is extremely important, and we always have to have horse patrol. But if we cannot respond in a timely manner to activity that is currently happening on the border, we are never going to be able to control the border and we are never going to be able to secure the border. Without that access, and without us being able to stop those people from entering into the country, we will never be able to secure the border.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Westerman

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: Another thing I noticed there was that it is a system of protection with walls and roads and remote-sensing equipment. And access is a critical component of that. Even if you have a wall in a remote area, people could figure out how to breach that. And if you can't access it, you can't stop them.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: Mr. Arthur, do you have anything to add to that on anything the Committee should know that you haven't had a chance to tell us?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Arthur

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Arthur

Statement.paragraph: Absolutely. I would commend to the Committee Section 118, Division C, Title I of the Securing America's Future Act. It will respond to a lot of the issues that Agent Judd and Mr. Bell have raised today about Border Patrol agents having their hands tied. Basically, what it would do is it would waive a variety of laws in very critical situations when Border Patrol needs to get access and needs to provide crucial infrastructure along the border.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Arthur

Statement.paragraph: In fact, I would expand it to include all laws so that state laws are not able to stop this critical work.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Westerman

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: The Chair now recognizes Mr. Beyer for 5 minutes.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Beyer

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Beyer

Statement.paragraph: Thank you, Mr. Chair, very much.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Beyer

Statement.paragraph: Mr. Nicol, I want to ask you about flooding. My friend Mr. Gosar talked about Nogales. There is the waiver authority in the border wall. What happened in 2008 in Nogales?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Nicol

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Nicol

Statement.paragraph: In 2008, seasonal monsoon rains that hit this area every 3 to 5 years came through Sonora and Nogales, Arizona. Rainfall that goes kind of from uphill in Mexico to downhill into the United States was dammed by the border wall that separates the two cities.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Nicol

Statement.paragraph: In addition to the wall above ground, there had been a wall built below ground, without discussion with the International Boundary Water Commission, that backed up water that was going through the drainage culvert underneath and caused the road above to heave up so that water was flowing along the top and pouring out of the ground. Water on the Mexican side was about up to the door frames. On the U.S. side, it was ankle deep. Hundreds of buildings were damaged and two people drowned in Mexico.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Nicol

Statement.paragraph: After that, there were efforts to retrofit border walls where they cross washes, but after that retrofitting occurred in 2011, water backed up behind a section of border wall in Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, a section that had been retrofitted. It then went over the top of the obstruction, carved out the foundation of the wall, and blew out a 60-foot wide section. We were told that that was an error and would not occur again, but in 2014 it occurred again, just outside of Nogales.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Beyer

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Beyer

Statement.paragraph: Would a NEPA analysis have made any difference in Organ Pipe National Monument or Nogales?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Nicol

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Nicol

Statement.paragraph: More than likely, because the land managers at Organ Pipe, before the wall went up, foresaw that walls were going to obstruct debris that would be going down awash during a flood. They actually commissioned a channel morphology report to be done as a baseline so they could see how it changed before the wall and after the wall. So, they saw it coming.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Beyer

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Beyer

Statement.paragraph: In my statement the last round, I complained about how candidate Trump and President Trump had promised that Mexico was going to pay for the wall. In his Fiscal Year 2019 budget we just got the other day, it has an $18 billion request for building the border wall across the U.S.-Mexico border, including 65 miles in the Rio Grande Valley. We all know that initial estimates tend to go way up. But my friend, Mr. Gosar, made some comment about how Mexico was actually paying.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Beyer

Statement.paragraph: I was going to ask Congressman Gosar, but he left, anyone understand what he said and could explain that to me, how currently we are expecting Mexico to pay for this wall, or some parts of it?

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Beyer

Statement.paragraph: This is a friendly question. It would have been a friendly question for him.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Arthur

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Arthur

Statement.paragraph: If I could, Mr. Beyer, I believe that the statement had to do with levee walls being built on either side of the border. And if there were to be a levee on the United States side and a levee on the Mexican side, that, in fact, would be a border wall that Mexico would pay for.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Beyer

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Beyer

Statement.paragraph: OK. Do we anticipate that much of the remaining wall that has to be built along the Mexican border is going to be these parallel levees?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Arthur

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Arthur

Statement.paragraph: That I can't answer. But it actually goes exactly to the point that Mr. Nicol made, because what he was saying was, if you put a wall on one side and you don't have a wall on the other, you end up having a flood control problem. If you cure the flood control problem, you cure it on both sides, and that is one way that you would alleviate the problem.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Beyer

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Beyer

Statement.paragraph: But we are also depending on Mexico deciding that they have to build a wall on their side.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Arthur

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Arthur

Statement.paragraph: As I said, I was surprised to see the Mexicans--there seems to be this impression that the Mexicans don't care about border security. This is a real bread-and- butter issue for them because they don't want the gangs in their country either. That is why I saw them cutting the carrizo cane in Ciudad Miguel Aleman. They don't want this, so, quite frankly, it is possible that that could happen.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Beyer

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Beyer

Statement.paragraph: Thank you.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Beyer

Statement.paragraph: Mr. Nicol, you talked about the Tohono O'odham Nation. It is a long history with the Border Patrol. Nevertheless, I understand that a waiver is used to construct a vehicle barrier across their land. Can you describe how that waiver affected the Tohono O'odham Nation?
Statement.speaker: Mr. Nicol

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Nicol

Statement.paragraph: They have complained that it has made it more difficult for them to interact with tribal members on both sides of the border. Their nation pre-exists the border being placed there. It restricts access to sacred sites and to family on the south of the border. And they have come out very strongly against converting that vehicle barrier into a pedestrian barrier as has been proposed.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Beyer

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Beyer

Statement.paragraph: OK. Mr. Chairman, I yield back. Thank you.
Statement.speaker: Mr. Westerman

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: The gentleman yields back.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

Statement.paragraph: I, again, want to thank all the witnesses for your valuable testimony, and the Members, to those that are still here, for our questions. The members of the Committee may have some additional questions for the witnesses, and we will ask you to respond to these in writing.

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman

paragraph.speaker: Mr. Westerman
